item.title: Israel’s Ultra-Orthodox Stage ‘March of the Million’ Against Military Draft
item.description: Hundreds of thousands took to the streets of Jerusalem on Thursday to protest against efforts to end an exemption from military service for Israel’s Haredi religious students.

item.title: Jamaica and Haiti Tally Hurricane Victims as Melissa Slams Cuba
item.description: About 20 people, including children, died in a Haitian community and at least three bodies were found in Jamaica, officials said, as they began to assess the huge storm’s damage.

item.title: How Xi Walked Away From Trump Trade Talks Looking Stronger
item.description: By withholding soybean purchases and rare-earth exports, China extracted relief from U.S. tariffs and delayed export controls, without conceding much in return.

item.title: Four Decades After It Was Stolen, a Renaissance Treasure Returns to Rome
item.description: The Italian art police still don’t know who took the brilliantly illuminated manuscript page from a Franciscan friary, and many more pages have yet to be found.

item.title: Wilders’s Far-Right Party Faces Rebuke in the Netherlands
item.description: Geert Wilders suffered a loss of support as a center-left party staged major gains, an election result that could offer lessons for Europe’s far right.

item.title: In Canada, a New Play Celebrates Indigenous Storytelling of the Northern Lights
item.description: The aurora borealis draws thousands of visitors to the Far North each year. A new play tells the lights’ tales from the perspective of Indigenous creators.

item.title: French Magazine Acknowledges Breaching Prince William and Catherine’s Privacy
item.description: The couple had sued Paris Match for publishing paparazzi photos of them and their children on a ski vacation.

item.title: Syria’s Rocky Transition Brings New Waves of Displacement
item.description: More than 400,000 Syrians have been displaced in the year since the civil war ended, according to the United Nations, driven by a mix of sectarian violence, acts of revenge and property disputes.

item.title: French Police Arrest 5 More in Louvre Jewel Heist Investigation
item.description: The authorities have detained seven suspects in total but have not recovered the stolen jewels.

item.title: For These Women, the American Dream Is in Mexico City
item.description: Thousands of foreign women have moved to the Mexican capital for a “life reset,” creating successful businesses and drawing more expats like them. Not all Mexicans are pleased.

item.title: Trump and Xi Ease Off the Trade War, but New Nuclear Threat Brings a Chill
item.description: The two leaders reached an agreement on fentanyl, some tariffs and rare earths, at least for a year. But even as the global trade picture cleared a little, Mr. Trump spurred new worries about nuclear proliferation.

item.title: Inside the Louvre Jewel Heist That Shocked the World
item.description: More than a week after thieves made off with treasures from the Louvre, a picture is emerging of a seemingly well-planned burglary that exploited security lapses at the museum and outpaced the police.

item.title: Far-Right Party Suffers Big Losses in Dutch Election as Centrists Surge
item.description: The progressive Democrats 66 gained seats and tied with the far-right party of Geert Wilders, which fell back sharply from a strong performance two years ago.

item.title: 2 Louvre Heist Suspects Have ‘Partially Admitted’ to the Crime
item.description: The Paris prosecutor overseeing the case said the two men face 15 years in prison for stealing some of France’s crown jewels, while two other suspects have yet to be caught.

item.title: Geert Wilders’s Party for Freedom Loses Seats in Dutch Election
item.description: A center-left party was poised to become the country’s largest political party, according to exit polls. The anti-immigrant Party for Freedom, led by Mr. Wilders, was expected to lose 12 seats.

item.title: He Studied Why Some Female Birds Look Like Males
item.description: Jay Falk explored a fundamental question: How do genes give rise to different bodies? But without funding, “there’s not really a future here.”

item.title: Candy Companies Are Quietly Cutting Down on Cocoa to Save Money
item.description: As climate change has helped push cocoa prices higher, companies are changing candy recipes in subtle ways.

item.title: Why a Cloud-Seeding Experiment to Fight Air Pollution in India Failed
item.description: Officials experimented with cloud seeding to try and reduce environmental pollutants as residents choke on filthy air.

item.title: China’s Pause on Rare Earth Controls: What to Know
item.description: China has suspended export controls announced this month, but was conspicuously silent about rules imposed earlier, which are snarling global supply chains.

item.title: U.S. Beef and Thousand Island Dressing: Trump’s Food Tour of Asia
item.description: The menus on the president’s tour of three countries in Asia reflected the culinary acrobatics the host nations performed to accommodate his palate and foreign policy goals.

item.title: He Survived the Invasion. What He Really Wanted Was a Friend.
item.description: During the war, a Ukrainian boy lost his home, his father and his friends. Could he find new buddies at a camp in the mountains?

item.title: Why the Price of Electricity Is Spiking Around the Country
item.description: Not all states have gotten hit equally hard. The reasons are complex.

item.title: Feted as a Peacemaker in South Korea, Trump Vows to End Hostilities With North Korea
item.description: President Trump lamented not being able to speak with Mr. Kim, the North Korean leader, but vowed to end the decades of hostilities between the two Koreas.

item.title: The Warnings Before the Hurricane
item.description: Island countries understood that a day like this would come.

item.title: Police Raid in Rio de Janeiro Leaves Over 130 Dead
item.description: The death toll in Rio’s deadliest police operation in history rose to 132 people, the state authorities say, sparking outrage and a reckoning.

item.title: U.S. Military Kills Four More People Accused of Smuggling Drugs on Boats
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said the latest strike took place on Wednesday in the eastern Pacific. It came two days after the deadliest set of strikes in the weekslong campaign in Latin America.

item.title: Melissa Leaves Black River, Centuries-Old Jamaican Port Town, ‘Totally Destroyed’
item.description: At least two people in the town died, and its historical buildings were reduced to rubble.

item.title: Hundreds Killed in Massacre at Sudanese Hospital, W.H.O. Warns
item.description: The hospital had served as the last refuge for many starving or injured civilians in El Fasher, a major battleground in Darfur recently seized by the Rapid Support Forces.

item.title: Judge Cuts Greenpeace Dakota Access Pipeline Award in Half
item.description: A North Dakota judge reduced the jury’s award to the pipeline company Energy Transfer to roughly $345 million, from $667 million.

item.title: As Trump Weighs Sale of Advanced A.I. Chips to China, Critics Sound Alarm
item.description: The president signaled he would discuss the sale of Nvidia’s Blackwell chips in a summit on Thursday, a move U.S. officials warned would be a “massive” national security mistake.

item.title: Protests in Tanzania as Voters Head to the Polls
item.description: The East African country’s Party of Revolution, one of the longest-ruling parties on the continent, seeks to keep its grip on power.

item.title: Chinese Officials Heap Praise on Trump and Xi Before They Meet
item.description: President Trump and the Chinese leader Xi Jinping are being described as “irreplaceable” and “world class leaders” before a meeting seen as critical for shoring up a trade truce.

item.title: U.S. Says It Will Cut Troops in Eastern Europe
item.description: About 700 troops are expected to be withdrawn as Trump administration officials shift resources to the Indo-Pacific region.

item.title: In Jamaica, Hurricane Melissa Brought ‘ Unprecedented Devastation’ U.N. Official says
item.description: Roads, infrastructure and the electricity grid were battered, and over one million people, a third of the population, were directly affected by the storm the official said.

item.title: U.S. Middle East Envoy Presses Lebanon to Disarm Hezbollah
item.description: The visit by the envoy, Morgan Ortagus, coincided with a spike in Israeli attacks on Hezbollah in recent weeks that has stoked fears of a renewed conflict.

item.title: How Japan’s New Prime Minister Bonded With Trump
item.description: President Trump met with Japan’s new prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, on Tuesday. Javier C. Hernández, The Times’s Tokyo bureau chief, looks at their chemistry, given the friendship Mr. Trump had with her mentor, the slain former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.

item.title: Video Analysis Shows Staged Recovery of Israeli Hostage Remains
item.description: Israel’s military released a drone video of the incident in Gaza, and The New York Times analyzed the footage.

item.title: Putin Announces Test of Tsunami-Making Nuclear Weapon
item.description: The test comes days after President Vladimir V. Putin announced the previous trial of another Russian nuclear weapon.

item.title: Israeli Strikes in Gaza Kill at Least 100, Local Health Officials Say
item.description: After what appeared to be the deadliest day since a truce deal was agreed on this month, Israel said the cease-fire had resumed.

item.title: The Netherlands’ Election Is a Referendum on the Far Right
item.description: Geert Wilders and his far-right party blew up the Dutch governing coalition this year. Will that cost their party seats in Parliament?

item.title: France Adds Consent to Its Rape Law After Yearslong Fight
item.description: The new legislation was adopted after dozens of men were convicted of raping Gisèle Pelicot while she was drugged by her husband.

item.title: As China and U.S. Split Over Energy, Korea Is Stuck in the Middle
item.description: It needs the United States for defense and has spent billions building factories in America. But a Trump trade deal this week with China could erase a Korean edge in the U.S. market.

item.title: Life Lessons from (Very Old) Bowhead Whales
item.description: A gene that helped bowheads adapt to frigid Arctic waters also granted them extraordinary longevity. Could it help aging humans become more resilient?

item.title: A River Restoration in Oregon Gets Fast Results: The Salmon Swam Right Back
item.description: The fish had been missing from the headwaters of the Klamath River for more than a century. Just a year after the removal of a final dam, they’ve returned.

item.title: U.N. Climate Adaptation Report Shows Declining Money for Climate Disasters
item.description: In 2021, rich countries vowed to spend more to help poor countries adapt to warming. That goal is unlikely to be met, a new report finds.

item.title: Mercedes Reports a Drop in Profit but Maintains Its Forecast
item.description: The German carmaker held its outlook steady and said it would buy back more than $2 billion in shares, as sales of its high-end models improved.

item.title: How the Opium War Still Shapes Xi Jinping’s Trade Clash With Trump
item.description: China’s leader draws on lessons from Lin Zexu, a Qing official whose defiance of Britain led to China’s humiliating defeat but made him a national hero.

item.title: China Outlines 5-Year Plan to Double Down on Global Tech Ambitions
item.description: Ahead of a meeting with President Trump, China’s leader signaled that he is committed to competing in manufacturing and technology despite tensions with Washington.

item.title: Street Battles Rage in Ukrainian City After Russian Troops Enter Stronghold
item.description: Moscow’s forces infiltrated Pokrovsk after months of attacks on the city, a strategic part of Ukraine’s eastern defenses.

item.title: Hurricane Melissa’s Direct Hit Knocks Most of Jamaica Offline
item.description: Most of the island of two million people was without internet service, and major airports were closed. Kingston, the capital, was mostly spared.

item.title: South Korea Gives Trump a Replica of an Ancient Gold Crown
item.description: President Trump received a replica of a golden crown excavated from an ancient royal tomb in Gyeongju. He called it “very special.”

item.title: Vietnam Prevents BBC Journalist From Leaving the Country
item.description: The reporter’s passport has been held by the authorities since August. Rights advocates want British officials to raise the issue with Vietnam’s visiting leader.

item.title: Japan Plans to Send Troops to Help Stop Bear Attacks
item.description: With the number of people killed by bears reaching a record nationwide, the defense ministry is preparing to send the military to one badly hit area to set traps.

item.title: When Caregiving Makes Women Ill
item.description: Eastern Europeans have migrated in droves to take care of Italy’s aged and infirm. Then they started getting sick, with an ailment dubbed ‘Italy syndrome.’

item.title: New Crack at an Ancient Puzzle Reignites Debate for Archaeologists
item.description: It is clear that the sprawling city of Teotihuacan near Mexico City was a major metropolis of the ancient world, but what do all those glyphs mean?
